RESOLVED_ENTITIES.U.S. Code Cong. & Admin.News: Official publication of US Congressional and Administrative materials
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.CLARK: CLARK, District Judge of the Western District of Louisiana
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Supreme Court: Supreme Court of the United States
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Western District of Louisiana: United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Juventino Mejia-Orosco: Defendant convicted of illegally transporting aliens into the United States, claimed sentence was too long, earns living trucking curios from Guatemala to the US
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hector Galvencio Paz-Ortega: Passenger and citizen of Guatemala, related to Juventino Mejia-Orosco
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Carlos Enrique Cruz-Morales: Passenger and citizen of Guatemala, related to Juventino Mejia-Orosco
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: Court responsible for making factual findings and imposing sentences, with the discretion to clarify ultimate factual findings through more specific findings when possible, calculated sentence according to guidelines promulgated by the United States Sentencing Commission, has fact-finding power in sentencing procedure
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States of America: Country where aliens were transported, also referred to as 'the government' in the context of law enforcement and sentencing
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Commission: Promulgated guidelines for sentencing used by the district court in calculating Juventino Mejia-Orosco's sentence, responsible for guidelines used in sentencing, specifies guidelines for sentencing, sought to ensure district courts consider all relevant factors, provided guidelines that permit a maximum sentence of no more than 7 months for similar cases
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals: Reviews the record and determines sentence validity, guided by the evidentiary basis for sentencing judgments provided by the district court's specific findings, gives due regard to the opportunity of the district court to judge the credibility of witnesses
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Congress: Legislative body that enacted sentencing guidelines to reduce disparity in punishment and ensure fair sentences, abandoned the rehabilitation model, aimed to make punishments fit the crime, concluded that predictions of an offender's propensity for or actual rehabilitation were unsubstantiated and incapable of scientific determination, enacted guidelines to provide a comprehensive approach to federal sentencing
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Senate Report: Official report containing information about Juventino Mejia-Orosco's case, provides context for the development of sentencing guidelines
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Official publication of US Congressional: Compilation of official US Congressional and Administrative documents, includes reports such as S.Rep. No. 225
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Commission Guid: Guidelines providing a framework for district courts to impose sentences, considering various factors for fairness and appropriateness, designed to reduce unacceptable disparity of punishment in the federal system, not intended to cover all contingencies or rigidly bind district judges, allows for departures from guideline-specified sentence when aggravating or mitigating circumstances are found
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Supreme Court of the United States: Recognized findings as factual and held that certain questions are factual, including whether cause exists to dismiss a venireman and the existence of discrimination, has jurisdiction over cases involving federal laws and the Constitution
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.CLARK, District Judge of the Western Dis: District Judge who made factual findings in Juventino Mejia-Orosco's case, has latitude to fine-tune sentence based on individual offender and circumstances of offense, affirmed the judgment and sentence of the district court
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court for the Wes: Court where CLARK is a District Judge
